results.notes:
on bark of branch of Pseudotsuga menziesii which extends out over the beach, about 2m above the beach
Quite surprising to me. Not feeling well that day and this was the only thing I photographed, as it looked interesting – seemed to be 2 lichens with one possibly parasitic on the other. Took a fingernail sized specimen which disappointed when examined at home as it didn’t include the 2nd lichen. When finally did microscopy I was surprised (and chagrined) to find it was another Sigridea californica. Had collected this a few km away in January. see https://mushroomobserver.org/484564?q=1maPA CNALH showed only one other collection north of southern Oregon, on Shaw Island about 25km west of mine. Wondering how abundant it is in the San Juan Islands. (The vicinity of Deception Pass is really superb for lichens.)
Any idea on the 2nd lichen (hope to collect some when next up that way) Jason?

For the 2nd lichen Jason suggested Arthonia or something in Arthoniaceae. Hopefully I will be able to obtain a specimen, but for now I think the morphology is consistent with Pachnolepia pruinata (Arthonia pruinata). Interesting that the CNALH map shows many collections in southern California, one in northern California, and then the next (15 or more) concentrated around the Salish Sea (a bit like the distribution of Sigridea californica). One of Curtis Bj√∂rk’s, about 3km from mine, has “habitat: Corticolous, trunk Pseudotsuga overarchinbg shoreline of lagoon”, essentially the same as mine.
results.location_name: Deception Pass State Park, Island Co. and Skagit Co., Washington, USA
Augusta, Georgia, USA

results.notes:
Remark in observation just posted of Sigridea californica that the vicinity of Deception Pass is really superb for lichens moves me to post some other lichens found in the general vicinity. Washington Park is about 10km away from there. Usually can find Cresponia chloroconia if look for it in the general area.
This is on maritime juniper, Juniperus scopulorum. See mostly on that and on Arbutus menziesii, but occurs others as well.

results.notes:
Found this on the ground. We recently had some heavy winds and rain, so I looked up and saw another two fruit bodies about 12 feet up the trunk of a young, but sickly looking oak. I used a fallen branch to knock off one of the smaller fruit bodies on the tree.

Very woody. I originally thought it might be Hexagonia hydnoides and compared it to the living specimens at home, but its thick and the cap is crusted in some places and hairy in others.

New to this site so let me know what else should be included.

notes_fields.Habitat: Scattered near the margin of several dehydrated brackets of Trichaptum biforme, that had been colonized by algae, on an exposed tree trunk.
notes_fields.Habit: Many
notes_fields.Remarks:
I didn’t notice this fungus when I photographed the Trichaptum biforme brackets in bright sunlight. iNaturalist detected them, as the first choice, when I uploaded the pics for observation https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/108741668.
I had assumed that this fungus was only found on T. biforme in moist, sheltered locations. These fruitbodies were found on dehydrated brackets of T. biforme on a tree trunk exposed to full sunlight.

results.notes:
Found on a steep east-facing slope of the east bay on which there might not be a single conifer, mostly oak and bay. smooth slightly pliable (almost brittle) shiny lacquered antlers stems and caps, pores turn brown when compressed, concentric rings of bright red growth fading to yellow-orange before the cap margin on the two larger non-antler individuals that were farther up the stump (each of whom was about a hand’s width and about an inch above the ground). pores white and visible when held at half arm’s length. As of yet, it is unclear if it was growing on oak or bay as the stump is very decayed. the two antlered ones were buried into the sand/clay-rich topsoil up to their pore layers peeking over a thin layer of oak/poison-oak(ahh)/bay/fern duff. I’ve been reading Terry Willard’s book on Reishi, and because he indicates it is quite rare to find antlers I unburied them cautiously to keep them as intact as possible and left the bigger caps up on the stump even though they were cleaner. at the time of this post they’ve been in the fridge for just under a day in a paper bag in a zip-lock bag. i’ll try propagating the very base of the antler stems onto wet cardboard then agar as tradd cotter recommends to avoid spreading the contaminants that might be lurking alongside their released spores. I can see some hyphal activity already even without cardboard! I’ll put everything but the regenerative stem base in a food dehydrator I think. But I’m real vexed cause I cant clean the dirt off at all without chipping off the cap’s outermost layer or I would make a tincture of one…. could I make a tincture with with the mushroom, dirt and all if I used 151 proof? maybe after storing them dry or washing with peroxide? Could I grind one real fine as a sanitization measure after drying then make a tincture?

Update on the 20th: I returned to the stump after yesterday’s light rain to find the other two still there (I wanted to at least give them a chance to release spores into the moistened surroundings before collecting, because rain is sparse this year and has been for the last few). I collected them both, as they are cleaner than the antlers, so I felt more sure that I could safely use them to make a tincture and possibly clone on agar. I added pictures of these.
Update: I got cultures from the contexts and stipes on MEA. The context is dark brown in most sections except near the growth margin where it is light brown with dark brown patterns.
Two months later: After a rare torrential late spring rain, I ran out to the stump and found Persephone (the fungus’ name) had produced yet another mushroom (on the weave, in the picture). I’ve been taking a tincture made from those I found in March, before going to sleep, and it is dependably soporific in a heavy sort of way. I made the tincture by drying the cleaned and chopped mushrooms in a food dehydrator, after tissue transfers, then putting them in a pint mason jar with 151 proof Everclear for just over half a month (until the liquid was a bright translucent golden-yellow) then strained the mushrooms out and put them in another jar to which I added almost-boiling distilled water; I let the emersion sit for seven hours, then mixed it with the other to wind up with around 45 to 50 proof.
I grew the cultures out on agar, transferred to rye then to sterilized and pasteurized oak sawdust (which they seem to take to about equally well. I lugged a couple of freshly felled bay logs out from near where I found it, and now they’re in the garden to be inoculated when the sawdust is fully colonized.

results.notes:
On a large decaying oak log.
Spore drop appears to lack pigment, but the spores are grayish in KOH.
Spores cylindrical, some slightly bent, some with thickened/rounded aplces; 12-18(23) x 3-5.
Asci clavate.
Paraphyses filiform, some with hooked apex. Some appear to be branched.
At first I thought this may be something like Annulohypoxylon. But the fruit bodies are not pimply "cramp balls. The surfaces of the fruit bodies winding flattened ribbon-like structures. Appearance reminds me more of a lichen than a fungus.
Spores dark gray in KOH, paler in H2O.

results.notes:
-Spore print is a pink-brown.
-Specimen stands at about 5-6 inches tall.
-Dark orange cap, with completely white stem and pink pores.
-No particular scent.
-Found growing next to a tree and a dead log.
-The mushroom was rubbery in texture, and became sticky after being picked for a while.
-No sign of any bruising when checked.
-Found within a neo-tropical rainforest.
-Closest look-alike I found was a burnt-orange bolete, however the pores are a different color.
-Mycorrhizal boletes typically found in Costa Rica are found at a MUCH higher altitude. This was a really bizarre/exciting find.
-I was there studying abroad, so I unfortunately did not have the option to dry it and take it back home.

results.notes:
Growing in Sphagnum at the edge of a bog. Caps dry; 6.5 to t0.8 mm wide and 4.2 to 6.3 mm tall. Stems cartilaginous; even; dry; smooth; 52.3 to 87.1 mm long and 0.8 to 1.3 mm wide. Odor not distinctive. Pileipellis hyphae with excrescences. Pileipellis vinescent in Melzer’s. Lamellar trama vinescent in Melzer’s. Lactifers abundant in the lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia abundant and similar to cheilocystidia. Cheilocystidia forming a sterile band; hyaline; fusoid-ventricose; smooth. Spores immediately amyloid and smooth. Spore measurements: (7.9) 8.5 – 10.9 (14.7) √ó (4) 4.5 – 5.9 (6.6) ¬µm; Q = (1.6) 1.7 – 2.2 (2.5); N = 30; Me = 10.1 √ó 5.2 ¬µm; Qe = 2

results.notes:
Fruiting in grass on the edge of Capitol Way/18th Ave Olympia, WA, USA.

Cap: silky, slightly umbonate, hygrophanous(drying lighter dull gray-see images).
Small papilla present at disc. NOT CONICAL.
Gills: gray, stained pink from spore deposit.
Stem: silver gray, striated, depressed centrally/vertically.
Odor: slightly farinaceous.
Harvested 3 specimens for further analysis/herbarium.
Spore printed mature cap directly on a glass slide for microscopy(images included).
Spore print: pink.
Spores: 5-6 sided, angular.
Dehydrated all 3 specimens and bagged for herbarium collection.
Note: This species(Group) seems to fruit most commonly from late February-early April in South Puget Sound, WA. I have noted and documented this for multiple seasons in Thurston County.

results.notes:
Identified by Keith N. Egger & Timothy J. Baroni
Spores pale, angular with 5-6 sides and a prominent apiculus, 10.5-(11.3 avg)-12.5 √ó 7.2-(8)-8.7 ¬µM. Basidia mostly (>80%) 4-sterimate, occasionally 2-sterigmate (<20%), clamped at the base. Cheilocystidia absent.
This is close to a GenBank sequence identified as E. cetratum by Hibbett (GenBank MZ919226: 98.85%). E. pallescens is close to x{GLOSSARYTERM E. cetratum }{ E. cetratum }x but differs in having 4-spored basidia. There are no sequences identified as E. pallescens in GenBank.
Sequence identical to MO #485740, GenBank OM716989.

notes_fields.Host: CA Pepper tree and cultivated Rosemary bushes
notes_fields.Habit: Very young to mature, dried. Several dense clusters at base of old, dead tree; six solitary or paired on roots of Rosemary nearby
notes_fields.Spore_Print: White deposit on top of lower caps
notes_fields.Smell_and_Taste: Smell – sweet; Taste very sweet then bitter/acrid
notes_fields.Size: Height to 13cm; Cap to 6cm wide

notes_fields.Cap: Red-brown, center flat or slightly depressed. Fibrils and scales on cap when young.
notes_fields.Spore_Structure: Gills adnate to decurrent; smooth edges; 3 series
notes_fields.Stipe: Cottony veil remnants, significantly dark on outer veil edge; brittle, breaks longitudinally; tan/shite
notes_fields.Base: Securely attached to wood from either tree or Rosemary bush.

results.notes: Appears to have killed very large 5’ wide base CA Pepper tree about 5 years ago and now killing 10ft section of mature cultivated Rosemary hedge (~12 ft from tree). Fruiting extends over 45 ft area on tree roots. No other fungi or insects found nearby.

results.notes:
A scattered group of around a dozen specimens growing singly or in small clusters in the sandy margin (not a bank) of an undisclosed stretch of Coopers Road (a sandy-gravel road open to vehicular traffic). This is Collection A labeled in the photos. Collection B was found in the same spot 7 days later. The whole road is surrounded by woods on both sides. The trees in the vicinity of the collections are pitch pines, a few arbovitae (probably Juniper virginiana) and 3 stunted and scrawny Betula populifolia (10-15 ft tall). The weather in New Lisbon, NJ, was 64-70/45-50 F at the end of October and only 54-61/28-40 F in the first 6 days of November (records from www. accuweather.com).
The morphology can be inferred from the photos, none of which, unfortunately, was taken in situ, as I was just hiking, not mushrooming, on both occasions. I also misplaced my notes, so the brief description below is based on the photos and memories. The caps were brownish gray with a pinkish tinge, the gills were “cinnamon-buff” to “pinkish-cinnamon” in R. Ridgway’s Color standards and color nomenclature (https://twitter.com/...). The largest cap of Collection A was only 4 cm wide, while the largest cap from the November fruiting was no more than 5.5 cm wide, and the stipe lengths were at the most half the cap width. The diminutive fruitbody size is not due to lack of precipitation, as the area had 2.5" of rain between Oct. 22 and Nov. 3, so I think this organism naturally produces basidiomata of a small stature. The crushed flesh had a pronounced odor of coconut and slowly tasted slightly acrid after about 10 sec., and the latex was watery to whitish, not staining the gills. This allowed me to successfully key this critter out to couplet 38 in Eastern Field Key Group A in Bessette’s milkcap book: L. glyciosmus, L. hibbardae var. hibbardae and L. hibbardae var. glaucescens. Sequencing this collection was the next step.
DNA sequencing results and discussion (posted 28-Mar-22):
A full-length consensus nrTS sequence of 637 bps long was obtained from two clean reads and posted here. A BLASTn-100 of this sequence gave a hit list that was difficult to interpret, but accessions called mammosus and glyciosmus were 98-100% similar to my query. I didn’t see any accessions labeled as “Lactarius hibbardae”. As a matter of fact, a subsequent search of this name in GenBank came back empty-handed. It’s also noteworthy that Bessette’s opus doesn’t mention L. mammosus.
To make sense of the BLASTn results, I needed to vet the accession through a reliable peer-reviewed publication. A search for “Lactarius mammosus phylogeny” led me to the 2016 Barge et al. publication (see the ref. in the proposal window). While the paper deals with a number of Lactarius documented in the Rocky Mountain area, the listed ITS accessions of L. glyciosmus and L. mammosus from Europe are plentiful. Based on the information in the text and the phylogenetic tree on p. 423 (posted here exclusively for educational and illustrative purposes as Fig. 1), I was able to establish that my collection is that of Lactarius mammosus: the ITS sequence is 99.67~99.84% similar to accessions AY097042, JF908316, KF133265, AJ633116, and FM992937 from Europe and 99.84~100% similar to KJ705202 & MN992611 from eastern Canada. At the same time, pairwise similarity to sequences of Lactarius glyciosmus and the mysterious Lactarius aff. glyciosmus listed in the study is 98.0~98.7%. It’s clear from the paper and BLASTn hits that both glyciosmus and mammosus are present in eastern and western North America, if one is to believe published ITS and RPB-2 data.
Barge et al. state on pp. 430-431: “Lactarius glyciosmus is morphologically and phylogenetically similar to L. mammosus; however, the latter has a browner pileus, stouter stature and more elongate, more reticulate basidiospores (Heilmann-Clausen et al. 1998). Phylogenetic placement of sequences isolated from ectomycorrhizal root tips of Pinus sylvestris L. (AJ633116, Heinonsalo et al. 2007) and Picea abies (L.) Karst. (FM992937, Kj√∏ller and Clemmensen 2009) confirm that L. mammosus associates with members of the Pinaceae; however, it also has been reported with Betula mainly in subalpine areas (Heilmann-Clausen et al. 1998).”.
My collection features small basidiomata, similar in size to L. glyciosmus and L. nanus, whereas L. mammosus of Europe is reported to be a larger, more robust mushroom. However, intra- and inter-specific variation in size and perhaps other macro- and microscopic traits is to be expected in this group of very closely-related taxa found on both sides of the Atlantic…
The question about the identity of Lactarius hibbardae Peck and hibbardae var. glaucens Hesler & A.H. Sm. remains to be answered.

results.notes:

results.notes:
Thallus of scattered, matte, gray-brown, convex areoles that appear to be broadly attached to the substrate. Micro: Thallus cortex thin, cellular, roughly 10-15 micrometers thick. Outer cortex dark brown (~5-8 micrometers thick) with poorly delimited hyaline layer of large cells below that, underlain by a consistent layer of algae. Thallus appears to have pycnidia, but the conidia (if that’s what they are) look like simple, hyaline spores! No apothecia on specimen.

I measured a few “conidia” and they measured: 7.8×3.3, 8.0×3.6, 8.7×3.9, 8.3×4.2 micrometers.

results.notes:
White resupinate polypore growing on hymenium of old Phellinus s.l. (Phellinus has multiple tube layers, brown skeletal hyphae, short setae, and tissue blackens in KOH) on old palm (?) stump. Cylindric hyphae of dissepiment edge lightly encrusted in H20. Small and large crystals sparsely present in trama/context. All hyphae appear to have clamps and are thin to thick walled, slightly inflated, and fairly homogenous (monomitic?) and subparallel in trama. Hyphae contents with small oil guttules. All elements inamyloid. Basidia 2(?) to 4 spored. Pores 3-4/mm, about 2mm long. Context about 3-4 mm (including part that grew into Phellinus pore layer). Cystidia absent. KOH on basidiome little change to tissue (sordid yellowish). (sent: Vlasak 4/11)

results.notes: Two specimens fruiting beneath Douglas fir. Note the ‚Äúironed on‚Äù appearance of cap patches and orange/apricot cap beneath. Short/stocky stem with only slightly bulbous base. Early Spring occurrence is to be expected with this species in South Puget Sound region(usually early April). I have documented this early Spring occurrence regularly here since 2009. This season is even earlier than normal which I can only attribute to the 100+F temps we had for nearly 2 weeks at the beginning of June in 2021. The expectation of late summer temps in June may be directly pushing back the fruiting time a few weeks to ensure longer fruiting period before having possibly stunted/scorched fruiting bodies. I will monitor this location from this point forward through summer to see what subsequent flushes produce. Harvested this mature fruiting body and dehydrated for herbarium collection.

results.notes:
Spores hyaline, polarilocular, ellipsoid. 3 measured (post-heating): 12.3×4.2×2.0; 12.0xx4.7×2.4; 12.4×5.7×2.0 micrometers. Septum notably narrow relative to spore size.

Macro: thallus not evident (endolithic). Apothecia up to ~1mm diam. Apothecia lecanorine, with orange disc and lighter yellow rim. Proper margin dominant and quite thick, raised above disc plane in younger aps, becoming flush with disc in older aps, but persistent. Margin often cracked/crenulate, most apparent in young apothecia. Micro: exciple below hypothecium distinctly paraplectenchymatous. Outer edge of margin also parplectenchymatous, composed of large cells. Outer exciple fans out becoming quite thick at the margin.

Habitat: river bank, frequently flooded terrain covered with organic river deposits; flat terrain, calcareous ground; moist and cold place, in half shade; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 8-10 deg C, elevation 528 m (1.730 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: moist humus soil and buried, almost completely disintegrated wood of (probably) Salix eleagnos.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soƒça and Trenta, left bank of river Soƒça, about 8 m off water stream, near the bridge to Matev≈æ, Trenta 1 farmhouse, East Julian Alps, Posoƒçje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: IF and Mycobank disagree regarding the current name of this species. IF uses Conocybe arrhenii as current name while Mycobank uses Pholiotina arrhenii as the legitimate name. The spore dimensions are a bit too wide and better fit to Pholiotina rugosa. Hence the determination may be questionable. On the other side habit (particularly the ring, which is whitish and placed mid-height) fits better to Pholiotina arrhenii.

Pilei diameter from 1.7 to 2.8 cm; stem thin, firm, elastic, hollow, 3.5 to 4.5 mm in diameter at the base somewhat thicker; spore print abundant, rusty‚Äìreddish-brown, oac762. Spores smooth or eventually minutely warty.

Camera: Sony ILCE6000 / Carl Zeiss Vario-Tessar E 16-70 mm/f4

results.notes:
Spores (from a white print) ellipsoid to sublacrymoid, 3.5-5 × 2-2.5.

As with these two older observations, the appearance matches the expectation for Physisporinus crocatus, but the shapes of the spores found does not fit the description seen on C du Q. This curent observation shows old fruit bodies, possibly the same ones as seen in the linked observations. I’m wondering if the spores found here (from a fairly substantial drop)… 1. may represent some other fungus growing on the polypore; 2. the spores of Physisporinus crocatus have walls that become weak and collapse.

results.notes:
On decomposed wood on forest floor. Smell not strong. Stipe hollow. Abundant mucronate pleurocystidia. Epicutis with a thin layer of filamentous hyphae on top of subcutis of pigmented (H20) inflated hyphae. Context hyphae same as subcutis, hyaline. Trama inflated cells purple in Meltzer’s, more or less hyaline in H20 and KOH. Spores inamyloid to weakly amyloid, most noticeable on developing spores still attached to basidia. No sign of bioluminescence (day later in dark room)

results.notes:
4 to 5 angled spores that are slightly under 10 um. Context with strong sweet smell, cotton candy (me) or key lime pie (yaritza), perhaps more accurately like sweet, slightly rancid coconut oil. Context turns slightly yellowish green when exposed. Large, cylindrical ventricose cheilocystidia and pleurocystidia present with brown contents. Although it seems to fit well with the concept of E. glycosmum, none of the cystidia were mucronate!

results.notes:
Large fruiting in a newly developed neighborhood/construction site. Construction began here Summer 2021. Recorded the location and returned again today(4/4/22) to see if any flushes had started. Abundant fruiting was surrounding a newly installed lamppost/street lamp.
Possible microclimate created by heat from lamps overnight. All fruiting bodies within 3 ft. of lamp post base. We have noted this occurrence under lampposts with M. importuna for over 10yrs in new developments(most abundant flushes always beneath lampposts).
Note the ladder like/vertically arranged pits.
Harvested 10 specimens for culinary use.
Left over 15 young fruits to mature in coming weeks.
Numerous Peziza sp. were also fruiting beneath lamppost, as well.
Dehydrated/bagged a single M. importuna for herbarium collection.
results.location_name: Olympia, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
On forest floor/litter with moss in an old-growth Eastern hemlock stand.
Taste mild. FeSO4 pinkish-brown (dry tissue); Guaiac no change (but tested on dry not fresh tissue). Spores elliptical, amyloid, echinulate, 6-(6.6 avg)-7.5 × 4.4-(4.7)-5.3 ¬µM. Cheilo- and pleurocystidia fusoid, thick-walled at apex, 35-45 × 7-10 ¬µM. Dermatocystidia fusoid, 1-2 septate, 3.6-(4.8)-5.6 ¬µM wide; fuchsinophile hyphae lacking.
ITS sequence >99% similar to GenBank vouchers identified as this taxon.

—

Found on the hiking trail behind General Hitchcock Campground around 6,100ft at the top of an old dead oak (Quercus arizonica, I believe) about 18-20ft up. Hoof-shaped to nearly resupinate fruit bodies, black crusty base with a light brown margin and light brown/cream pore surface. Corky/woody context. Margin and cap surface have a very rough texture. Most bodies were around 1-3cm in diameter but there was a large ~8cm diameter specimen as well. 3-5 rounded pores per mm with relatively thick walls between each pore. Pores 4mm or so deep.
